element.name: station
element.label: geographic location
element.description: The details of the geographic location that you want to simulate. Note that the coordinates affect different parts of the model, e.g., Coriolis rotation and solar radiation.

element.name: time
element.label: period
element.description: The period that you want to simulate.

element.name: timefmt
element.label: type of period specification
element.description: method to specify start and of model run

option.label: start date and number of time steps

element.name: grid
element.label: column structure
element.description: The column structure determines the accuracy and detail with which the water column is resolved. You can selectively increase the detail of parts of the column by changing the grid type.

element.name: grid_method
element.label: type of vertical grid
element.description: By changing the grid type, you can control the detail with which different parts of the water column are resolved. A study of bottom friction benefits from a small layer height near the bottom (bottom zooming), while a study of biological process is better served by a layer height near the surface (surface zooming). Custom grids allow you to specify the height of every level individually.

element.name: nlev
element.label: number of layers
element.description: The number of depth levels used to describe the water column. More levels increase accuracy and result resolution, but also simulation time.

element.name: ddu
element.label: surface zooming
element.description: Grid zooming (surface), 0: no zooming; > 3 strong zooming

element.name: ddl
element.label: bottom zooming
element.description: Grid zooming (bottom), 0: no zooming; > 3 strong zooming

element.name: grid_file
element.label: custom grid
element.description: File for sigma or cartesian grid. the first line gives the number of layers, the following lines give fractions or layer heights in m from the surface down to the bottom.

element.name: c1ad
element.label: weighting factor for adaptation to buoyancy frequency

element.name: c2ad
element.label: weighting factor for adaptation to shear frequency

element.name: c3ad
element.label: weighting factor for adaptation to surface distance

element.name: c4ad
element.label: weighting factor for adaptation to background

element.name: NNnorm
element.label: normalisation factor for adaptation to buoyancy frequency

element.name: SSnorm
element.label: normalisation factor for adaptation to shear frequency

element.name: dsurf
element.label: normalisation factor for adaptation to surface distance

element.name: dtgrid
element.label: time step for grid adaptation (must be fraction of dt)

element.name: dt
element.label: time step
element.description: Time step for integration. The time step affects the accuracy of the results: smaller time steps improve accuracy, but come at the expense of simulation speed.

element.name: cnpar
element.label: "explicitness" of numerical scheme
element.description: Constant for the theta scheme used for time integration of diffusion-reaction components. θ=0.5 for Cranck-Nicholson (second-order accurate), θ=0 for Forward Euler (first-order accurate), θ=1 for Backward Euler (first-order accurate). Note that only θ=1 guarantees positive solutions for positive definite systems.

element.name: MaxItz0b
element.label: number of iterations for hydrodynamic bottom roughness
element.description: Number of iterations for calculating the hydrodynamic bottom roughness from the bottom friction velocity and the physical bottom roughness.

element.name: charnock_val
element.label: empirical constant for surface roughness adaptation
element.description: Empirical constant in Charnock 1955 formula (default = 1400).

element.name: z0s_min

element.label: set shear production term to zero

option.description: From equation of state, i.e. from (potential) temperature and salinity.

element.label: equation of state
element.description: choice for empirical formula for equation of state

option.label: UNESCO, Fofonoff & Millard (1983)
option.description: UNESCO equation of state by Fofonoff and Millard (1983)

option.label: Jackett et al. (2005)
option.description: equation of state according Jackett et al. (2005)

option.label: full equation, local pressure
option.description: full equation of state (i.e. with the local pressure). This implies that temperature values throughout the program are treated as in-situ temperatures rather than potential temperatures.

option.label: full equation, surface pressure
option.description: equation of state with pressure evaluated at the surface. This implies that temperature values throughout the program are treated as potential temperatures (as oposed to in-situ temperatures) and thus densities as potential densities.

option.label: linear, reference pressure prescribed
option.description: linear equation of state with reference temperature, salinity and pressure prescribed. Expansion coefficients are calculated once at the prescribed pressure; specify the surface pressure to work with potential temperature and density.

option.label: linear, expansion coefficients prescribed
option.description: linear equation of state with reference temperature, salinity, thermal expansion coefficient and saline expansion coefficient.

element.name: flux_source
element.label: surface flux specification
element.description: Surface fluxes can be calculated from observed meteorological variables, or be specified explicitly as fluxes of heat and momentum.

element.name: rain_impact
element.label: include effect of rain fall on fluxes of sensible heat and momentum

element.name: const_heat
element.label: constant surface heat flux
element.description: Constant value for the surface heat flux, i.e., the sum of the sensible, latent and back-radiation fluxes (but not short wave radiation).

element.name: heatflux_file
element.label: custom heat fluxes
element.description: custom heat fluxes (negative for net outgoing)

option.label: calculated from time, location and cloud cover

element.label: scale factor for short wave solar radiation

element.name: momentumflux_file
